“Can science help religion, and can religion help science?” They help each other as cohesively as mist and fire. Science helps dispel religious assertions, and religion helps people remain ignorant of reality. So religion keeps the scientifically inept out of science, and the intellectually inquisitive out of religious fundamentalism. There is no point of convergence between the two. Science is the pursuit of knowledge, wherever that may lead, and whatever the answers may be. Religion is the assertion of bronze age superstitions, regardless of knowledge or where that knowledge actually leads and the answers it actually provides.

Science could help religion. Apply rational fact-based reasoning to religion would drive out unreliable ideas. Of course that would probably help religion into the grave. But it would be good for religion. Religion can’t help science. It requires people to believe mystical things with no basis in fact. That’s the anti-thesis of rational fact-based reasoning and would debase the value of science to engage with religion in anything but a one-sided flow of ideas.
